In ''Taking Out the Trash'' (editorial, Dec. 11), you say that building more incinerators is a ''logical response'' to growing solid waste.

The environmental consequences of incineration do not justify the claimed benefits. Incinerator ash is extremely toxic, and is buried in Long Island landfills. Even operating within Department of Environmental Conservation and Environmental Protection Agency limits, incinerators still emit carcinogens and irritants to the cardiopulmonary systems, causing cancer, bronchitis and emphysema. They also add to global warming.
The solution is to cut the waste stream, reuse packaging and increase recycling. Incineration may be a cheaper way of dealing with waste, but good health is worth the expense.
The writer is coordinator, Sustainable Energy Alliance of Long Island.
